# Standard 1 - Analytical approaches

*This standard relates to your involvement in the adoption and strategic decision-making in relation to the selection of analytical tools and techniques across your team and the wider organisation..*

| SP1.1 Identify                                                                                                 | *What was the situation and analytical challenge? Which                               | I was asked to find the smoking prevalence for mental health patients in the care of the Trust. Although smoking status had been recorded in two forms over the years the prevalence had never been calculated, only current smokers counted for [CQUINs](<https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/health-matters-preventing-ill-health-from-alcohol-and-tobacco/health-matters-preventing-ill-health-from-alcohol-and-tobacco-use>). Also, as the smoking status was not recorded regularly, to work out the yearly prevalence would require assuming smoking status for the years when they had an open referral but no smoking status recorded. I originally only had SQL and Excel as tools to complete this so I used SQL to combine data which counted: |                   |
| which tools and techniques are most appropriate for the situation and justify                                  | tools were available to complete the task? | the measures used. These situations will sometimes be non-routine although                                     | What were the benefits of using this particular tool? Where there any disadvantages?* | 1.  an assessment in a referral/inpatient stay                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   |                   |
| precedents are likely to have been established before within the team.                                         |                                                                                       | 2.  an assessment before a referral/inpatient stay and assumed no change in smoking status in the interim period                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |                   |
| Demonstrates a critical understanding (including researching) of the organisation and health care environment. |                                                                                       | 3.  an assessment after a referral/inpatient stay and assumed no change                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          |                   |
|                                                                                                                |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |                   |
|                                                                                                                |                                                                                       | SQL was the only way I could script this logic to make it reproducible but when I was asked to update this I moved to R as this is a more flexible analytical and statistical language. By moving the code to another language I validated my previous logic and I realised it was better to produce a row for each year between assessments and fill down the missing years. I also had mistakenly counted the ages based on the admission dates and, of course, everyone ages each year so I changed the age calculation to be on the first of every year. This isn't quite accurate but is much closer than my initial approach.                                                                                                                              |                   |
|                                                                                                                |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |                   |
|                                                                                                                |                                                                                       | I used RMarkdown to produce the workflow to bring the data together, including the ONS smoking prevalence data, manipulate this to create a new dataset and the produce statistics from it. This meant I could write more narrative around the analysis which, when it was in SQL was left as comments in the script and not shared.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             |                   |
|                                                                                                                |                                                                                       |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |                   |
|                                                                                                                |                                                                                       | The downside to using R was only that it takes longer in R than in SQL, due to RAM needs, to fill the missing data if the dataset is a couple of million rows. I got around this by using a package called {data.table} which, whilst I'm not familiar with, is much faster at processing data than my usual package of choice, {dplyr}.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |                   |

# Standard 2 -- Critical Application
